Ryuji is a task management chatbot that allows users to interact with their to-do lists via a simple chat interface. Users can add, delete, mark, unmark, and search for tasks, all through text-based commands. The bot supports various task types like `ToDo`, `Deadline`, and `Event`, and can persist tasks across sessions in a CSV file.
- **Search**: Find tasks by labels or descriptions.
- **Task Persistence**: Tasks are saved to a CSV file so that they persist across sessions.
- **User Interaction**: A chat-like interface for interacting with the bot.
- `mark <task number>` – Mark a task as completed.
- `delete <task number>` – Delete a task from the list.
- `find <keyword>` – Search for tasks containing a specific keyword.
- `help` – Display a help message with command usage.
- **Java 8+**: Make sure you have Java installed. You can check your Java version with:
- **IDE**: You can use any Java IDE, such as IntelliJ IDEA, Eclipse, or Visual Studio Code, but this project has been built with Intellij in mind.
To clone the repository and set up the project locally:

If you don't want to build the application from source, you can download a pre-built **JAR file** (Java Archive) for this application. The JAR file contains all the necessary code and dependencies to run the application.
1. Go to the [releases page](https://github.com/BoredFurry/ip/releases) of the project (replace with actual URL).
3. Save the `.jar` file to a directory on your machine where you can easily access it.
### 1. Import into your IDE or Build from Command Line
- If you're using an IDE like **IntelliJ IDEA** or **Eclipse**, simply **import the project** as a Gradle project.
- Alternatively, you can **build the project** from the command line using **Gradle**.
1. **Clone the repository** or download the source code.
If you are using Git, clone the repository:
If you don't have Gradle installed, use the **Gradle Wrapper** to build the project:
This will compile the code, run tests, and generate the JAR file. After building, you will find the JAR file in the `build/libs` directory (e.g., `build/libs/ryuji-chatbot-1.0.jar`).
3. **Run the application** using the following command:
4. **Interacting with the chatbot**: Once the application is running, a GUI window will open, and you can interact with the chatbot as described in the [Usage](#usage) section.
If you downloaded the JAR file from the releases page, you can run it directly without needing to build the project.
1. **Download the JAR file** (as described in the [Setup](#setup) section).
2. Open a terminal or command prompt and navigate to the directory where the JAR file is located.
3. Run the application with the following command:
4. **Interacting with the chatbot**: Once the application is running, a GUI window will open, and you can interact with the chatbot as described in the [Usage](#usage) section.
### Notes on Running the JAR File
- When running the JAR file, make sure that you have **Java 11** or higher installed on your system.
- If you are running into any issues related to Java versions, please ensure your environment variable `JAVA_HOME` is set correctly.
- If you encounter any issues running the JAR file, you may want to check the logs or console output for any error messages. You can try troubleshooting by checking your Java version or dependencies.
- The application will automatically create a `tasks.csv` file if it doesn't already exist. This file will store all the tasks you add through the bot.
- The CSV file will be saved in the root directory of the project.
- If the file doesn't exist, the bot will initialize an empty task list for the session.
- When you first run the application, it will show a **welcome message** and prompt you to interact with the bot.
- The interface includes a **task list** and a **user input field** where you can type commands.
After running the application, you will interact with the **Ryuji chatbot** through a graphical user interface (GUI). Below is a breakdown of how to use the application:
When you first launch the application, the **welcome message** will appear, along with a prompt asking you:
This marks the beginning of your interaction with Ryuji. You can now enter your commands.
Here is a list of all the available commands you can use in the chatbot:
- **list**: Displays all the tasks currently in the task list.
- **todo [task description]**: Adds a **ToDo** task with the specified description.
- **deadline [task description] /by [date]**: Adds a **Deadline** task with the specified description and due date.
- **event [task description] /at [time/place]**: Adds an **Event** task with the specified description and date/time.
- **delete [task number]**: Deletes the task at the specified position.
- **mark [task number]**: Marks the task at the specified position as completed.
- **unmark [task number]**: Unmarks the task at the specified position as incomplete.
- **find [keyword]**: Searches for tasks that contain the specified keyword in their descriptions.
- **help**: Displays a help message with a list of all available commands.
- **bye**: Exits the application. A farewell message will appear and the program will terminate after a brief delay.
### 3. How to Interact with the Bot
- Type a command into the **input field** at the bottom of the window.
- Press the **send button** or hit **Enter** to send the command.
- The bot will process the command and respond with the result:
- If you add a task, it will confirm that the task has been added.
- If you mark or unmark a task, it will show the updated task status.
- If you delete a task, it will confirm that the task has been removed.
- If you search, it will show the tasks that match your search term.
This will add the task "Buy groceries" to the task list.
This will add the task "return book" to the task list and indicate the time "(by: Monday 3pm)".
This will add the task "JMOF" to the task list and indicate the duration "(from: January 9th 2026 to: January 11th 2026)".
this will mark the first task as complete
this will unmark the first task
To display the current tasks you have, type:
this will show your current task list
this will delete the first task. to check the result, call list
this will bring up all tasks that contain that search term
If you require further assistance, you may type:
and a help message will appear explaining the available functions
Welcome to RyujiCafe, here is the menu:
In this cafe, you can keep track of tasks so that you can focus on doing them
Types of tasks I can assist with:
Commands to help you with your list of tasks:
result: first item will be removed from the list
result: ends the chat with Ryuji
Go ahead and try some of these commands";
Once you are done and wish to exit, you may type:
this will allow Ryuji to say farewell and the application will close
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
## Be sure to try out all the other commands Ryuji has to offer!
* Represents a command that adds a new task to the task list.
* This command is responsible for adding a task to the task list, saving it to storage,
* and displaying a confirmation message to the user.
/** The task to be added to the list. */
* Constructs an {@code AddCommand} with the specified task and command keyword.
* @param command the command keyword indicating the type of task to add
* @param task    the task to be added to the task list
* Executes the add command, which involves adding the specified task to the task list,
* saving the task to storage, and showing a confirmation message to the user.

*

This method delegates the task addition to the {@code TaskList} and
* instructs the {@code Storage} to save the task to the file system.
* @param tasks   the current {@code TaskList} containing all tasks
* @param ui      the {@code Ui} used to display messages to the user
* @param storage the {@code Storage} used for saving task data to persistent storage
* @return a confirmation message indicating that the task has been successfully added
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
* Abstract base class for all commands in the Ryuji chatbot application.

*

Each command represents an action triggered by user input. Subclasses of {@code Command}
* implement specific behavior for different actions such as adding tasks, marking tasks as done, etc.
* Constructs a {@code Command} with the specified command keyword.
* @param command the command keyword string representing the user's input
* Returns the command keyword string for this command.
* This keyword is typically used to match the user’s input.
* @return the command string representing the user's input
* Indicates whether this command signals the application to exit.
* By default, this returns {@code true} if the command string equals "bye".
* Subclasses may override this behavior to provide different exit conditions.
* @return {@code true} if this command is an exit command (e.g., "bye"), {@code false} otherwise
* Executes the command, performing its intended action.
* This method must be implemented by subclasses to define the specific action associated
* with the command (e.g., adding a task, marking a task as done).
* @param tasks   the current {@code TaskList} containing all tasks
* @param ui      the {@code Ui} component used to interact with the user
* @param storage the {@code Storage} component used for managing persistent data
* @return a message or result indicating the outcome of executing the command
public abstract String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage);
* Returns a string representation of this command.
* The string is typically the command keyword (e.g., "todo", "mark", "bye").
* @return the string representation of this command keyword
* Represents a command to delete a task from the task list.
* This command is responsible for removing a task from the task list and updating the persistent storage.
/** The 1-based position of the task to be deleted. */
* Constructs a {@code DeleteCommand} with the specified command and the position of the task to delete.
* The position is a 1-based index representing the task's position in the list.
* @param position the 1-based position of the task to delete
* @throws AssertionError if the position is less than or equal to 0
assert position > 0 : "use a number that is greater than 0";
* Executes the delete command by removing the task at the specified position from the task list
* and updating the storage file to reflect the change.

*

If an error occurs during the deletion from storage, a message is returned indicating the failure.
* @param tasks   the current {@code TaskList} containing all tasks
* @param ui      the {@code Ui} component used for user interaction
* @param storage the {@code Storage} component responsible for managing persistent data
* @return a message indicating the result of the deletion (success or failure)
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
return "There was an error trying to remove your task master: " + e.getMessage();
* Represents a command that exits the application.

*

When executed, this command shows a farewell message to the user and gracefully exits the application.
* Constructs an {@code ExitCommand} with the given command keyword.
* Executes the exit command by displaying a farewell message to the user.
* No changes are made to the task list or storage. This method provides a graceful exit
* and shows the user a farewell message.
* @param tasks   the current {@code TaskList} (not used by this command)
* @param ui      the {@code Ui} component responsible for user interaction
* @param storage the {@code Storage} component responsible for persistent data (not used by this command)
* @return a farewell message displayed to the user
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
* Represents a command to search for tasks that contain a given keyword.

*

The {@code FindCommand} filters the list of tasks based on a search term
* and displays the matching tasks to the user. It allows the user to quickly locate tasks
* related to a specific keyword or phrase.
* The term to search for within the task descriptions.
* This term is used to filter the task list for tasks that match the search term.
* Constructs a {@code FindCommand} with the specified command keyword and search term.
* @param searchTerm The term to search for within the task descriptions.
* Executes the find command by filtering the tasks that contain the search term
* and displaying the matching tasks through the UI.

*

This method delegates the task filtering to the {@code TaskList} and returns
* a string representation of the matching tasks.
* @param tasks   The current {@code TaskList} containing all tasks.
* @param ui      The {@code Ui} instance used to display messages to the user.
* @param storage The {@code Storage} instance used for saving/loading tasks (not used in this command).
* @return a string representation of the tasks that match the search term.
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
* Represents a command that displays help information to the user.

*

This command provides an overview of the different task types (ToDo, Deadline, Event) and
* the supported commands in the Ryuji task management system.

*

When executed, it displays a guide containing examples of usage for each command available in the application.
* A formatted multi-line string that contains all the help instructions
* and examples of commands that the user can use.
private final String HELPMESSAGE = "Welcome to RyujiCafe, here is the menu:\n" +
"In this cafe, you can keep track of tasks so that you can focus on doing them\n" +
"Types of tasks I can assist with:\n" +
"Commands to help you with your list of tasks:\n" +
"    result: first item will be removed from the list\n\n" +
"    result: ends the chat with Ryuji\n\n" +
"Go ahead and try some of these commands";
* Constructs a {@code HelpCommand} with the given raw command string.
* @param command the raw user input that triggered this command
* Executes the help command by displaying the help message through the UI.
* This method does not modify the task list or the storage.
* @param tasks   the current {@code TaskList} (not used in this command)
* @param ui      the {@code Ui} instance used to display messages to the user
* @param storage the {@code Storage} instance (not used in this command)
* @return the help message that provides usage instructions for various commands
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
* Represents a command to display the full list of tasks to the user.

*

The {@code ListCommand} is used to show all tasks currently stored in the {@code TaskList}.
* Constructs a {@code ListCommand} with the specified command keyword.
* Executes the list command by displaying all tasks in the current {@code TaskList}.
* This method uses the {@code Ui} to present the task list to the user.
* @param tasks   the current {@code TaskList} containing all tasks
* @param ui      the {@code Ui} used to interact with the user and display the task list
* @param storage the {@code Storage} handler (not used in this command)
* @return a string representation of the entire task list to be displayed
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
* Represents a command to mark a task as done in the task list.

*

This command updates the task's status to "done" and provides a visual confirmation to the user.

*

It changes the task's state and notifies the user that the task has been marked as completed.
/** The 1-based position of the task to be marked as done. */
* Constructs a {@code MarkCommand} with the specified command string and task position.
* The position is a 1-based index representing the task's position in the list.
* @param position the position of the task to mark in the task list (1-based index)
* @throws AssertionError if the position is less than or equal to 0
assert position > 0 : "Position must be greater than 0";
* Executes the mark command by updating the status of the specified task.
* This method changes the task's status to "done" and returns a confirmation message.
* @param tasks   the current {@code TaskList} containing all tasks
* @param ui      the {@code Ui} used for displaying messages (not used in this command)
* @param storage the {@code Storage} responsible for saving task data (not used in this command)
* @return a message indicating that the task has been marked as done
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
return "There was an error trying to mark your task master: " + e.getMessage();
* Represents a command to unmark a task (i.e., mark it as not done).

*

This command modifies the task's status by unmarking it as completed, and provides feedback via the UI.

*

It changes the task's state back to "not done" and notifies the user accordingly.
/** The 1-based position of the task to be unmarked. */
* Constructs an {@code UnmarkCommand} with the given command string and task position.
* The position is a 1-based index representing the task's position in the list.
* @param position the position of the task to unmark in the task list (1-based index)
* @throws AssertionError if the position is less than or equal to 0
assert position > 0 : "Position must be greater than 0";
* Executes the unmark command by updating the status of the specified task.
* This method changes the task's status to "not done" and returns a confirmation message.
* @param tasks   the current {@code TaskList} containing all tasks
* @param ui      the {@code Ui} used for displaying messages (not used in this command)
* @param storage the {@code Storage} responsible for saving task data (not used in this command)
* @return a message indicating that the task has been unmarked as done
public String execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
return "There was an error trying to unmark your task master: " + e.getMessage();
* Handles reading and writing of CSV-like data files stored on the desktop.

*

This class provides methods to read, write, and update task data stored in a file.
* The file is used to persist tasks between application sessions. Tasks are read as CSV rows, and the
* class ensures that the file is created if it doesn't exist.
/** The absolute path of the file used for storing tasks. */
/** An instance of the {@link Ui} class used for interacting with the user. */
private final Ui ui = new Ui();
* Constructs a {@code Storage} object with the specified file name.

*

If the file does not already exist, it will be created on the user's desktop.
* @param fileName the name of the file to store tasks
* Reads the file from the specified path and parses its contents into tasks.

*

The file is assumed to have a CSV format, where each line represents a task. The tasks are returned
* as a list of {@link Task} objects.
* @return a list of tasks parsed from the file
ui.showError("Sorry master but your file does not exist: " + filePath);
ui.showError("Sorry master but I cannot read that file: " + filePath);
ui.showError("Sorry master but I can't read this task:\n" + lineNum + ": " + line);
* Writes a task to the file in CSV format.

*

The task is serialized as a CSV row and appended to the file.
* @param task the task to be written to the file
* Helper method to write a row to the file.

*

This method is used to append a new line to the file.
* @param row the row to be written to the file
ui.showError("I had trouble writing the file into your storage master: " + e.getMessage());
* Writes a row to a specified file.

*

This method appends a row to the given file.
* @param row  the row to be written to the file
* @param path the path of the file to write to
public void writeToFile(String row, String path) {
ui.showError("I had trouble writing the file into your storage master: " + e.getMessage());
* Creates a temporary file path for updating the CSV file.

*

The temporary file is used to store updated data before replacing the original file.
* @param filename the name of the file to generate the path for
* @return the generated file path for the temporary file
* Removes a task from the file at the specified position.

*

This method reads the original file, skips the line at the given position, and writes all other lines
* to a temporary file. The original file is then deleted, and the temporary file is renamed to replace it.
* @param position the 1-based line number of the task to be removed
* @throws IOException if an I/O error occurs during reading, writing, or file manipulation
public void removeTaskFromFile(int position) throws IOException {
* Updates the status of a specific task in a CSV file by replacing the line at the given position with
* the new task's information. The method reads the original CSV file, writes the updated task
* information to a temporary file, and then replaces the original file with the temporary one.
* @param position The line number (1-based index) of the task to be updated in the CSV file.
* @param task The task object containing the updated information to be written to the file.
*             The task is converted to a CSV row format using its {@link Task#toCsvRow} method.
* @throws IOException If an I/O error occurs during file reading, writing, or renaming operations.
public void updateTaskStatus(int position, Task task) throws IOException {
* Returns the file path where the task data is stored.

*

This method is used to retrieve the absolute path of the file where tasks are persisted.
* Utility class for handling various date and time formats.

*

This class provides methods to parse, detect, and format date-time strings in different formats.

*

The supported date-time formats include both date and time (with time being optional) and different local
* and international date-time representations. Currently, it supports date formats such as "yyyy-MM-dd" and "yyyy/MM/dd".
/** Input formatter patterns to parse date and optional time (time is optional). */
private static final List<String> patterns = List.of(
/** Output formatter to display the date in a user-friendly format. */
* Parses a given date-time string into a {@link LocalDate} object.

*

This method attempts to detect the format of the provided string using predefined patterns.
* If a valid format is detected, the string is parsed into a {@link LocalDate} object. If no valid
* format is found, the method returns null.
* @param dateString the date-time string to parse
* @return the parsed {@link LocalDate} object, or null if no valid format was found
System.out.println(formattedDate);  // Debug output, can be removed for production.
* Formats a given {@link LocalDate} object into a user-friendly string representation.

*

This method uses the predefined output formatter to convert the {@link LocalDate} into a string
* @param parsedDate the {@link LocalDate} object to format
* @return the formatted date string, in the form "MMM d yyyy" (e.g., "Sep 15 2025")
* Represents a task with a deadline.

*

Deadline tasks have a specific due date and time, and this class handles parsing and formatting
* flexible date/time input. The supported formats include "yyyy-MM-dd" and "yyyy-MM-dd HHmm".

*

For example, a deadline task can be created with input such as "deadline return book /by 2019-12-02 1800".
/** Parsed date-time if input matches expected format; null otherwise. */
/** Raw date-time string used as fallback if parsing fails or no standard format. */
* Constructs a Deadline task from a command string.

*

This constructor splits the input string by the "/by" keyword, with the first part representing the task label
* and the second part representing the date/time of the deadline.

*

If the date/time format is valid, it is parsed and stored. Otherwise, the raw date/time string is stored.
* @param input the full command string including the deadline date/time (e.g., "deadline return book /by 2019-12-02 1800")
* Constructs a Deadline task with a marked status from a command string.

*

This constructor is similar to the previous one, but it also allows setting the task's completion status directly.
* @param input    the full command string including the deadline date/time (e.g., "deadline return book /by 2019-12-02 1800")
* @param isMarked true if the task is marked as done, false otherwise
* Checks if this deadline task has a valid date/time.

*

The task is considered valid if it has either a parsed date or a non-empty raw date string.
* @return true if the deadline has a valid parsed date or a non-empty raw date string, false otherwise
* Returns a CSV row string representing this task.

*

The format for the CSV representation is: "D | status | label | date/time".

*

If the task has a parsed date, it will be used in the CSV row; otherwise, the raw date/time string is used.
* @return a CSV-formatted string representing this deadline task
* Returns a user-friendly string representation of this deadline task.

*

The task string will include the task's status, description, and the deadline date/time.

*

If a valid parsed date is available, it will be formatted and shown in the output. Otherwise, the raw date/time string is shown.
* @return a formatted string including the task status, description, and the deadline date/time
* Represents an event task with a start and end date/time.

*

Event tasks represent events that occur at a specific time range, with a start date/time and an end date/time.
* This class handles parsing and formatting flexible date/time input, supporting formats such as "yyyy-MM-dd"
/** Parsed start date-time, or null if parsing fails */
/** Parsed end date-time, or null if parsing fails */
/** Raw start date/time string, fallback if parsing fails */
/** Raw end date/time string, fallback if parsing fails */
* Constructs an Event task from the full command string.
* @param input the full input string including event description and times
* Constructs an Event task with a marked status from the full command string.

*

This constructor allows you to set the task's status (marked or not) directly.
* @param input    the full input string including event description and times
* @param isMarked true if task is marked done, false otherwise
* Checks if the event has valid start and end date/time.

*

This method checks if both the start and end times have been correctly parsed or provided as raw strings.
* The event is considered valid if it has either valid parsed date/time or raw date/time for both start and end times.
* @return true if both start and end times are valid (parsed or raw)
* Returns a user-friendly string representation of the event.

*

The task string will include the event's status, description, start date/time, and end date/time.
* @return string formatted as "[E]<task info> (from: start to: end)"
* Returns a CSV row string representing this event task.

*

The format for the CSV representation is: "E | status | label | start date/time | end date/time".
* @return CSV formatted string of this event task
return String.format("E," + status + "," + label + " /from " + startStr + " /to " + endStr);
* Abstract base class representing a generic task item.

*

This class provides the core functionality for all task types, including:

*

Concrete subclasses such as {@code ToDo}, {@code Deadline}, and {@code Event}
* should extend this class and implement specific validation and data serialization logic.
* Indicates whether the task is marked as completed.
* The textual description or label of the task.
* Constructs a {@code Task} with the given label.
* @param label the task's label or description
* Constructs a {@code Task} with the given label and completion status.
* @param label  the task's label or description
* @param status the completion status (true if completed, false otherwise)
* Checks whether the task is valid.

*

This method must be implemented by subclasses to perform type-specific validation.
* @return {@code true} if the task is valid; {@code false} otherwise
* Unmarks the task (sets it as not completed).
* Returns the status icon for the task.

*

The icon will be "X" if the task is marked as completed; otherwise, a space character " " will be returned.
* @return "X" if the task is completed; otherwise, a space character " "
* Checks whether the task's label contains the specified search term.
* @param searchTerm the keyword to search for in the label
* @return {@code true} if the label contains the search term; {@code false} otherwise
* Converts the task to a CSV-compatible string array for persistent storage.

*

This method must be implemented by subclasses to include task-specific fields (e.g., dates, description).
* @return a string array representing the task's fields, formatted for CSV storage
* Creates a {@code Task} object from a CSV row.

*

The first element of the row should indicate the task type: "T" for ToDo, "D" for Deadline, or "E" for Event.
* @param row the CSV row containing the task data
* @return a {@code Task} object reconstructed from the row; or {@code null} if the type is invalid
* Returns a string representation of the task, including its status icon and label.

*

This method generates a simple string like: "[X] Task description" where X represents the completion status.
* @return the formatted string representing the task, including its status icon and label
* Represents a list of {@link Task} objects with operations to add, delete, mark,

*

The {@code TaskList} provides various functionalities to manage a collection

*
  • Adding a new task to the list

*
  • Searching for tasks based on a label

*
  • Displaying all tasks in the list with their respective status
* The internal list that stores tasks.

*

This constructor initializes the task list as an empty list.
* Constructs a {@code TaskList} with the specified list of tasks.
* @param tasks the list of tasks to initialize the task list with
* Adds a valid task to the list. If the task is invalid, it will not be added
* and an error message will be returned.

*

This method checks if the task is valid by calling its {@code checkValid()}
* method. If valid, the task is added to the list and a success message is returned;
* otherwise, an error message is returned.

* The {@code Ryuji} class serves as the main entry point for the Ryuji chatbot application.

*

This class is responsible for initializing the user interface, task list, storage, and parser.
* It manages the core logic of the chatbot by reading user input in a loop, parsing commands,
* It interacts with the task list to modify tasks, and it communicates with the user through the user interface.

*

This constructor initializes the storage using the provided file path.

* it initializes an empty task list and notifies the user of the failure.

*

If no file path is provided, this constructor will attempt to load tasks from the default storage file.
* If loading fails, it initializes an empty task list and notifies the user.

*

This method displays a welcome message, then enters a loop to continuously read, parse,

* and ensures that the user can interact with the chatbot until they choose to exit.
* Generates a response for the user's chat message.

*

* It also handles any exceptions that occur during the parsing or command execution.
* @return the chatbot's response as a string
